{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3493878,"name":"Mitchell","username":"Winrich5","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/ee59a6/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-27T18:37:08.083Z","cooked":"

So my team is trying to run a command without a subsystem. All that this command does is post Limelight X Y and Area found in limelighthelpers file, to smartdashboard. This part works when we trigger it with a button press.
We want to run this command without pressing the button. We tried a few ideas like

*new LimelightCommand();
and
*joystick.b().whileTrue.(new LimelightCommand());
*joystick.b().whileFalse.(new LimelightCommand());

*this is purely from memory so format might be incorrect

So my question is, is it possible to run a command without a trigger? and are we overthinking it?

Thank you for any input.

You can use triggers which are not buttons. The code you describe (posting values to SmartDashboard) with a regular function you can run in a periodic loop.

you can run it inside robotPeriodic() or teleopPeriodic()

Youâ€™ll probably want to put it inside a public method on RobotContainer that is then called from robotPeriodic, otherwise youâ€™ll find yourself making everything public.

An idiom we use a lot is
new Trigger(DriverStation::Enabled).onTrue(/*command*/)

This will launch a command whenever the robot is enabled, no buttons or subsystems needed.

You could also just replace the condition with new Trigger(()->true).whileTrue(/*command*/) , but at this point itâ€™s likely youâ€™ll want to use a Periodic function somewhere. We make our Vision systems a proper subsystem in part to ensure that we have a dedicated vision periodic function and other bundled operations. This also enables the option for exclusive control if you want to temporarily change a pipeline, or something of that sort.
